2022 – 2027 Aerial Imagery Plan

Assumptions
• Hold cost to 240k per year so same cost to each partner as the previous 
seven years
• Urban captured every year (perhaps add sphere of influence?)
• Rural 1/3 of county captured each year
• All imagery acquired at 3 “ 4 bands.
• Obliques captured
• QL1 LIDAR for roughly 10 % of county/budget constraint (split amongst 
partners and justified by REGIS
• Planimetric updated or new (with change detection);
• Building outlines
• Edge of pavement
• Parking lots/runways/tarmacs

Goal
• Submit plan to select vendors for pricing
• Sanborn
• EagleView
• Continental
• Others?
• Vendors present proposals
• Working group selects best vendor (cost and technical)
• Adjust deliverables to hold the line on cost
• BOS approves multi-year contract, and all partners sign multi-year cost sharing 
agreement prior to BOS approval
• Place order by end of September 2021
Vendors must have SaaS solution for Obliques and ability to add oblique widgets to Apps
Must meet technical requirements for accuracy
All flights leaf-off flown in February/March each year

Questions

Solano County ReGIS Meeting 
Meeting Minutes – June 16, 2021 
 
Shital called to order the regular meeting at 9:06 am on June 16, 2021 via Zoom. 
I. 
Introductions 
The following persons were present: Shital Dhakal, Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Donald 
Hildebrandt, Curt Corbett, Jasmin Acuna, Bao Nguyen, Becki Brooks, Brent Rosenwald, Alex Lacson, 
Mark Unwin, Rosaly Zambrana, Stephanie Baker, Justin Pascual, Rowland Roberts, Kathrina Gregana. 
II. 
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business 
A. No questions nor comments were brought up for the May 19 meeting minutes and was accepted by 
the group. 
B. New Business: 
1. Shital: 
a. Upcoming changes posted on the Federal Register website pertaining to NAD83 and 
NAVD88 national standards for geodetic coordinates. The modernization of the 
National Spatial Reference System will replace the current standards with four new 
frames and one new datum. Change will occur between 2022 and 2025. NOTE: 
Sanborn aerial imagery will be submitted in CA State Plane WGS 1984. 
b. Vexcel Imaging is an aerial imaging company that provides free imagery for areas 
claimed as a disaster zone. It is not necessary to be under contract with them. 
Becki asked if Pictometry provided free imagery with all the fires in the area last 
year, per Jasmin they did not provide the service because it wasn’t covered in the 
contract. Under Sanborn’s contract, they also only provide free service if a disaster 
was due to specific occurrences - tornado, hurricane, earthquake 7.0 or greater, or 
terrorist/man-made attack, fire is NOT covered. 
2. Curt asked if other agencies use Metroscan Corelogic, a software specializing in parcel data, 
residential, commercial, industrial and vacant property, wherein one of their tools is a 
multiple mailer solutions. Vacaville has had requests of historical data for parcels but were 
redirected to the County because their (Vacaville) data is not always current. They also have 
developed a public notification mailer tool on AGOL where employees have their embedded 
login credentials so login is instantaneous. It also has the capability to export to an excel 
spreadsheet, send mailers to the situs address and/or owner address. Most of their users 
are in public works and community development, about 50-60 accounts. 
a. No other agency is using Metroscan. 
b. Solano County preserves parcel data at the end of the year. They will not provide 
transfer dates, telephone numbers in their GIS data. 
c. Fairfield hasn’t used Metroscan in a while and uses current assessee owner 
information. 
d. Shital has used ParcelQuest in the past, data update is every 6 months, data 
simplified in a user-friendly interface. They have a widget to print out their own 

Solano County ReGIS Meeting Minutes – June 16, 2021 
 
2 of 3 
 
mailing labels. Metroscan provides archived data of previous parcel ownership and 
transfer data. 
3. Jasmin – Fairfield is working with MTC for emergency evacuation planning maps, provided 
building outlines and street centerlines using the County GIS hub. MTC in turn has provided 
data to FF. No other agency has received data from MTC. Vacaville has preset evacuation 
routes for high threat evacuation boundaries, no knowledge of MTC providing data to them. 
Jasmin will forward data to the group. Nellie asked how MTC data compares with PG&E 
emergency routes but Jasmin has not compared the data yet. STA is not familiar with 
emergency routes but will find out. Nellie to provide Jasmin and the group a link to PG&E 
PSPS portal page and other information from PG&E. 
4. Stew – Solano County GIS websites will be consolidated, re-configured and completely 
revamped by July, including the SharePoint page ReGIS members were using. They’re 
working with a webposting company to assist with this project. 
III. Discussion 
A. Workgroup Updates: 
1. Aerial Imagery (Stew) – QA/QC this July. Sanborn’s Project Status report was forwarded to 
ReGIS members. Any questions or comments should be forwarded to him. See attached 
slideshow. 
a. Looking into a 6-year contract, 2022 to 2027 - 3” res 4-band Near IR imagery with 
urban areas and sphere of influence. County to be divided into 3 unincorporated 
sections and captured triennially. Ability to access obliques on any apps. SASS 
solution is required. Meet all technical requirements for accuracy. Leaf-off flights. 
b. Planimetric data this year will encompass building outlines, edge of pavement, 
parking lots/runways/tarmacs. Will continue to capture planimetrics for 
unincorporated areas flown and in urban areas updated annually. 
c. In 2 weeks the aerial imagery scope will be presented to the committee for review, 
then to vendors for proposal, vendor presentation, vendor selection by committee. 
Solano County BOS to approve the 6-year contract. A new County standard E-sign 
contract will be distributed for all stakeholder agencies to sign. 
d. No cost increase from previous years! 
2. NextGen911 Workgroup Updates (Stew) – consultant Geocomm maintaining street 
centerlines, offered extra service to convert existing street centerline data attribution to the 
NextGen911 standard format. 
a. $75,000 grant opportunity, where a portion will be allocated towards an enterprise 
system, BCS The Addresser tool. Sac County is using this tool and is happy with it. 
They provide the software, the tool is nonproprietary, runs on top of the ESRI 
enterprise portal is compatible with the County’s Azure website portal. Stew will 
arrange for a demo of the BCS The Addressor tool, perhaps around August. 
b. Solano County has taken a different approach from previous NextGen911 
discussions, to outsource the parcel data maintenance to Geographic Technologies 
Groups. There will be two full time staff dedicated solely to 1. street centerlines 
and 2. parcels. Additional plan is to move all street centerlines, address points and 

Solano County ReGIS Meeting Minutes – June 16, 2021 
 
3 of 3 
 
LAFCO boundaries to the cloud, to provide a collaboration platform for ReGIS 
agencies. They will have full responsibility for their jurisdictional parcels/address 
points and street centerlines. 
3. Shital asked if other agencies are using the ESRI parcel fabric… Stew responds that it is not 
on the table at this time, perhaps 1 to 2 years away. Assessor parcels are still an issue, and 
currently undergoing a massive cleanup. Until a more precise base layer is produced, they 
will not be using ESRI’s parcel fabric. 
a. Curt mentioned their workflow for parcel generation starts with a DWG file 
converted to a SHP file to developing vertical data. It is not easy to use parcel fabric 
mainly due to idiosyncrasies of CAD submittals not meeting GIS topology rules. 
b. Curt asked Stew if they are thinking of spearheading CAD standards for parcel 
submissions, Stew’s response is that assessor parcels involve deeds, surveyed 
“closing” geometry and politics it would be a huge blockage to the assessor approval 
and recording processes. So, although Stew’s GIS goal for SC is to move towards 
excellence, establishing digital GIS standards for parcels is not currently at the 
forefront. 
 
B. Executive Team Updates: 
1. Schedule for in-person ReGIS meetings – no comment at this meeting. Could be added to 
the GIS Survey Stew is preparing. 
2. Lightning Talk – it would be nice to learn more about the awesome GIS work each agency 
has developed for their daily workload. Looking for volunteers to do a quick 5-minute talk 
about their projects. Shital has volunteered. Stew is looking into having one of their staff to 
participate… open to all! 
3. Plans to invite other GIS professionals – potential item on the questionnaire. 
4. GIS Survey – Stew, in progress. Berkeley may have one. Identify top 5 governance priorities 
for the group. May use Survey123 for the questionnaire. 
IV. Action Items 
1. Jasmin – MTC information about emergency routes. 
2. STA – find out if there was communication with MTC

Solano County ReGIS Meeting 
Meeting Minutes – July 21, 2021 
 
Shital called to order the regular meeting at 9:06 am on June 16, 2021 via Zoom. 
I. 
Introductions 
The following persons were present: Shital Dhakal, Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Donald 
Hildebrandt, Curt Corbett, Jasmin Acuna, Bao Nguyen, Mark Unwin, Stephanie Baker, Jeff Bertany, 
Rowland Roberts, Kathrina Gregana, Scott – Sanborn, Bridget Marcotte - Sanborn. 
II. 
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business 
A. No questions nor comments were brought up for the June 16 meeting minutes and was accepted by 
the group. 
B. New Business: 
1. Shital: RouteSmart – company based in Maryland for intelligent routing systems. Vallejo is 
interested in this type of technology for their street sweeping program and potentially other 
programs. Fairfield has a Street Sweeping webapp that contains preplanned routes and 
zones for street sweeping, search by address and zoom to the zone and schedule. Also uses 
the same webapp builder for trash collection. Vacaville uses the Recology.com street 
sweeping app similar to the functionality Fairfield’s webapp. 
2. Jasmin: pushback from FFPW with LAFCO city limit layer after their review. Parcel layers in 
GIS is generally digitized and not based on metes and bounds. LAFCO city boundary layer is 
based on legal descriptions which may pose legal ramifications should there be 
misalignments with other datasets. Curt spoke with Jeff Lum, LAFCO, there’s pushback from 
their public works as well because of misalignments with other jurisdictional datasets such 
as police and sheriff response boundaries, impacting RIMS. The LAFCO layer will not be 
published on any Vacaville’s public website at this point. Per Stew, LAFCO is the 
authenticated owner of the boundary layer wherein the Cities need to come into an 
agreement. The County will eventually adopt LAFCO’s dataset for basemaps and other 
applications displaying city boundaries. No parcel nor street centerline adjustments will be 
made until LAFCO officially ‘certifies’ the data. Executive director of LAFCO plans to setup a 
date to meet with Vacaville, Fairfield and Suisun City for review of the previously 
disseminated city boundary datasets. County GIS is under contract to maintain boundary 
files for LAFCO, they’ve already spent approximately 7 months revising boundary files, 
affecting fire, water districts; impacting tax maps. It’s estimated that it will take 
approximately 2 years to adjust these datasets using LAFCO city boundary as the basemap. 
3. Stew – released a parcel layer in July via WeTransfer. Another update will be in August and 
accessible via the Azure portal, external access with logins. They will also have a REST URL 
for the parcel approx. Aug-Sep timeframe. The County has a side project with SID to update 
parcels along their utility lines after new aerial imagery is released. 
4. Stew – looking into Corelogic/RealQuest for parcel data. 

Solano County ReGIS Meeting Minutes – July 21, 2021 
 
2 of 3 
 
III. Discussion 
A. Workgroup Updates: 
1. Aerial Imagery (Stew) – Monday (July 26 +/-) they will release an RFP for 6-year contract. 
Sanborn to present on the oblique viewer. 
2. NextGen911 Workgroup Updates (Stew) – will hire the same consultant who is currently 
working on parcels to work on street centerlines and address points, they offered the extra 
service of converting existing street centerline data attribution to the NextGen911 standard 
format. 
a. $72,000 funding to purchase BCS The Addresser tool. 
b. Interested in RouteSmart for a routable street centerline. The ultimate goal is for 
the cities to have primary control of their streets within their incorporated area and 
have one unified dataset for the entire county. With this project, they will work 
closely with RIMS centers to correlate the data with GIS. Long process but will get it 
done. 
c. County working with 4 GIS positions, 2 dedicated to parcel data, 2 dedicated to 
street centerlines. 
3. 
Bridget – presented Sanborn Oblique Viewer. 
a. 
Can Google map be the first image to the extent of Solano County and not the 
imagery? Bridget will find out. 
b. 
Enhance accessibility to the high-res imagery in the box below versus having a 
small button in the compass wheel. Bridget says it may not be optional but will look 
into it. 
 
c. 
Does the URL button ‘copy to clipboard’ to street view or imagery? Per Bridget’s 
demo it defaults to the imagery. She will look more into it. 
d. 
Scott (Sanborn) mentioned that certain layers could be defaulted ON with the 
imagery. Asking a consensus on default ON layers. Recommended to be mindful of 
specific default layers, such as parcels, may be taxing on bandwidth, slowing down 
speed response. Connecting to a service file or uploading a shapefile may be 
quicker. 
e. 
Search box on the middle left side searches any loaded attribute data. Searching 
large parcel data may not zoom in accurately. Per Stew, parcel centroids can be 
developed to enhance search. Is it possible to multiple search parcels? Bridget will 
look into this. 
f. 
Sanborn will be meeting with TAFB next week to discuss Search functionality and 
other uses of the application specific to their required security protocols. 

Solano County ReGIS Meeting Minutes – July 21, 2021 
 
3 of 3 
 
 
g. 
Flight date in upper right corner date of the last group capture, lower left indicates 
when the flight imagery was actually captured. 
h. 
Sanborn is open to end users preferences to produce a great product for all 
stakeholders. 
 
B. GIS Survey – should be completed within a week or so. Plans to have one focused on Governance 
priorities, the other to learn other agencies’ GIS projects and needs. 
C. Lightning talk – postponed for next meeting – crime mapping, not a live data feed. Jasmin 
volunteered as the next presenter. 
IV. Action Items 
1. Sanborn to address questions by attendees. 
2. All – review Sanborn imagery via GeoServe. 
3. Stew to request a demo of BCS Addresser tool. 
4. All - other potential presentations by vendors, consultants, other local public agencies. 
5. All - Lightning Talk volunteers? 
6. STA – find out if there was communication with MTC about emergency routes. This was a question 
that Jasmin brought up in the last meeting since they have been sharing data with MTC. 
V. 
Adjournment 
Meeting was adjourned by Shital at 10:00am. Next ReGIS monthly meeting will be 9:00am Aug. 18.

Solano County ReGIS Meeting 
Meeting Minutes – August 18, 2021 
Stew called to order the regular meeting at 9:06 am on August 18, 2021 via Zoom. 
I.
Introductions
The following persons were present: Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Donald Hildebrandt, Jordan
Santos, Stephanie Baker, Mariah Henderson, Alex Lacson, Curt Corbett, Jasmin Acuna, Mark Unwin,
Rowland Roberts, Kathrina Gregana, Nicole Braddock, Ryan Branciforte.
II.
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business
A. No questions nor comments were brought up for the July 21 meeting minutes and was accepted by
the group.
B. New Business:
1.
Suisun City (Roland): asking if other agencies have contracts with Interwest, their GIS
consultant. The company seems to have internal staff restructuring and some have left for
Infinity Technologies. Vacaville uses Interwest as well and is experiencing the same
predicament.
C. Nicole Braddock, Executive Director of Solano Land Trust with Ryan Branciforte - OuterSpatial
presentation about their countywide parks and recreation project, link to presentation.
1.
Map-based mobile app to locate CA State Parks within the community categorized by types
of activities, similar to the AllTrails app but more. Other data includes parking, trails, PDF
maps, parks, restroom facilities, etc. They would also like to provide red flag day warnings,
so working with local fire agencies and emergency response.
2.
SLT is highly encouraging sharing data with them to improve the data for SC and the
community we serve. Don and Stew are the main contacts, any information that will be
shared by other cities should funnel through them.
3.
SLT uses maps daily and considers ReGIS peeps as “unsung heros” স
হ
঺
঻
4.
Partnering with Kaiser Permanente with Take a Hike Challenge and other companies to get
people to engage in outdoor activities.
A.
Workgroup Updates:
1.
Aerial Imagery (Stew) – final review Tuesday August 24, moving along well. Sanborn and
Eagleview are vying for the contract. Eagleview has a more user-friendly oblique viewer, but
Sanborn’s quote is more feasible, leaning more towards the latter. Multi-agency agreement
will be forwarded to stakeholders soon. NO INCREASE FOR THE NEXT 6 YEARS. Looked into
more partners for the contract, however most of the agencies are relatively small and may
not monetarily contribute. TAFB may not sign the agreement but has contributed
financially.
2.
NextGen911 Workgroup Updates (Stew) – GeoComm is working on the parcel update, street
centerlines and address point layers, unsure if they’ll continue to work with the County after
their contract has ended. SC is working on a countywide address point layer, many thanks

month SC plans to roll out an ArcGIS online EOC app. Working on integrating Alert Solano 
app, live feed into SC EOC app. Also integrating fire calls into RIMS, special views for 
dispatch to city partners. 
B. GIS Surveys – should be completed within a week or so. Plans to have one focused on Governance 
priorities, the other to learn other agencies’ GIS projects and needs (later this year). Goal is to select 
the top 5 items (out of 20) as ReGIS’ framework. Recommendation is to limit the distribution of the 
questionnaire to IT/GIS staff. 
C. Datasharing agreement – SC has one in place but basically says all agencies in the consortium will 
have access to data, with the exemption to confidential data. Their Azure portal will serve as a one 
stop shop, REST services will also be available. 
III. Action Items 
1. Stew to request a demo of BCS Addresser tool. 
2. All – think of potential presentations by vendors, consultants, other local public agencies. 
3. All - Lightning Talk volunteers? Shital, Jasmin, Stew (Digital Twin, metaverse towards the end of the 
year). 
IV. Adjournment 
Meeting was adjourned by Stew at 10:00am. Next ReGIS monthly meeting will be 9:00am Sep. 15.

Meeting Minutes – September 15, 2021 
 
Stew called to order the regular meeting at 9:06 am on August 18, 2021 via Zoom. 
I. 
Introductions 
The following persons were present: Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Jordan Santos, Mariah 
Henderson, Curt Corbett, Jasmin Acuna, Mark Unwin, Kathrina Gregana, Matt Hardy, Bao Nguyen, Justin 
Pascual, Rebecca Brooks, Francis, Tim Flanagan. 
II. 
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business 
A. No questions nor comments were brought up for the August meeting minutes and was accepted by 
the group. 
B. New Business: 
1. Curt – Vacaville is moving forward with Infinity Technologies, formerly Interwest, same with 
Suisun City. 
2. Jasmin – Fairfield is implementing a new application for permitting, replacing Trackit with 
EnerGov, Munis ERP name, Tyler Technologies. Stew installed EnerGov with a previous 
employer and will be a good resource for implementation. Curt would like to have input 
with EnerGov as they are thinking of a new permitting software as well. Jordan, with Dixon, 
is wanting feedback as well. 
3. Stew - Solano County Regional GIS Portal is in progress, looking for people to be pilot people 
for testing the new site. Stakeholders will be able to login to the portal to obtain any data, 
and access REST services to data. 
A. Workgroup Updates: 
1. Aerial Imagery (Stew) – final review of 6-year contract, moving forward with using SanBorn 
as the vendor/consultant. Multi-agency agreement will be forwarded to stakeholders soon. 
NO INCREASE FOR THE NEXT 6 YEARS. Looked into more partners for the contract, however 
most of the agencies are relatively small and may not monetarily contribute. TAFB may not 
sign the agreement but has contributed financially. Question about Napa’s interest in 
imagery… Stew - not at the moment but approached Isaac Cabrera, CA State’s GIO. Seems 
like a huge undertaking to partner with agencies statewide, but may look into it in the 
future.

Solano County ReGIS Meeting 
Meeting Minutes – October 20, 2021 
 
Shital called to order the regular meeting at 9:05 am on October 20, 2021 via Zoom. 
I. 
Introductions 
The following persons were present: Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Shital Dhakal, Jordan Santos, 
Mariah Henderson, Jasmin Acuna, Mark Unwin, Kathrina Gregana, Matt Hardy, Bao Nguyen, Justin 
Pascual, Rebecca Brooks, Francis, Tim Flanagan, Stephanie Baker, Danny Fortson, Sheri Speakman, 
Michael Deprato. 
II. 
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business 
A. September Meeting Minutes: Jasmin asked about the 6-yr contract for aerial imagery flyover, Stew 
mentioned it will be addressed later in the meeting. No additional comments were brought up, 
moved for acceptance by Stew and seconded by Shital. 
B. New Business: 
1. Jasmin – Fairfield has a new IT director, Savita Chaudhary, from the City of Berkeley and 
before that an employee of the City of Vacaville who also attended ReGIS meetiongs. One 
of the first endeavors is to generate a GIS Master Plan. 
2. Stew - Solano County Azure cloud is fully functional with ITIL framework. There will be a call 
for individuals to test out the site soon. Shital requested that the County IT team provide a 
presentation of ITIL framework and was agreeable by Stew. 
3. Shital – asked if other agencies are using/looking into using Metroscan. Fairfield has used 
Metroscan about 12 years ago, currently receiving parcel tabular data from the County. 
With inhouse programming mechanisms to run queries to detect inconsistencies with the 
data, the workflow seems to work for now. Stew mentioned that the County is behind 
about 9 months with parcel data updates and is working with CoreLogic to assist with 
resolving this issue but this is a huge undertaking and will take some time. 
4. GIS Day – it is not feasible to conduct an in-person event. Stephanie, ESRI, commented that 
it is quiet this year, but feel free to check out ESRI’s website for virtual events. 
5. Rowland – looking into a new GIS consultant, Interwest has dissolved. Vacaville is moving 
forward with Infinity Technologies, formerly Interwest. Other companies mentioned were 
Carollo, Farallon Geographics and West Yost. 
III. Discussion: 
A. BCS Inc The Addresser presentation (mp4) 
• 
Where does the data reside? The Addresser is configured in ArcGIS Portal so data resides in 
ArcSDE or ArcGIS datastore but compatible with any platform. Per Stew, the plan is to post 
this application on the County’s Azure portal so the data will reside in a PostgreSQL DB.

street centerlines, integrating with several RIMs DB, and pulling in other multi-jurisdictional

B. Aerial Imagery (Stew) – final review of 6-year contract, moving forward with using SanBorn as

Status Report 
 
 
Prepared by: Bridget Marcotte, Sanborn Map Company, 719-244-2311 
Report Date – January 7, 2022 
 
Provided to: Solano 2021 Project Team 
Current Status 
• 
Orthoimagery Status 
o We released the orthoimagery via Sanborn Image QC™ for client review on July 23, 2021. 
▪ Client completed review August 27, 2021. Sanborn made corrections and released 
via Sanborn Image QC™ for review on September 13, 2021. Sanborn has received 
some feedback accepting corrections and notice to move forward with product 
production on October 25, 2021. 
▪ Sanborn provided examples of final formats and compression ratio for client review 
and confirmation on October 29, 2021; received client feedback January 6, 2022. 
▪ Orthoimagery tiles in GeoTiff format and project-wide mosaic will be delivered in 
State Plane and Web Mercator formats. All other data/products will be delivered 
(planimetrics, obliques, DEMS) will be in SP projection only. Per email on Oct. 29, 
2021 and revised January 5, 2022 
• 
Oblique Imagery Status 
o We completed the aerial triangulation (AT) and processing the oblique imagery. 
o Delivered oblique imagery via Sanborn Oblique Analyst® on June 28, 2021 
▪ 
Conduct meeting on July 1 to review Sanborn Oblique Analyst® application tools and 
function. 
▪ 
Separate instance for Travis AFB has been setup. 
▪ 
Sanborn will add vector layers (parcels, streets, city bndry and county bndry) when 
received 
▪ 
Sanborn will setup separate instance with credentials once the vector data is 
received. 
• 
 Planimetric Status 
o Delivered pilot tiles via Sanborn FTP on June 16, 2021; conducted meeting on July 9, 2021; 
client confirmed parking lot guidance on August 17, 2021. We updated the pilot tiles based 
on the guidance and redelivered with building data on Sept. 10, 2021. Client approved 
revised pilot data on Sept. 28, 2021. Delivered the full AOI on October 19, 2021 and 
redelivered November 3, 2021 with buildings outside the boundary included. Pilot area was 

excluded from the full AOI. It has been added in and data uploaded to FTP January 5, 2022. 
Waiting on client feedback or approval. 
▪ Data will be delivered with building updates 
▪ Only existing buildings within the project AOI will be updated. Buildings outside of 
the County boundary but within the project AOI will not be added as it is outside of 
the SOW. 
▪ Existing lidar is not in the format needed to extract the building heights. Sanborn 
investigated alternative solutions using imagery created DSM.

Technical Issues 
• 
Client has concerns with the alignment of planimetric and WMTS data in ESRI software. Initial 
investigation showed transformation set in ArcPro verse ArcMap. Client reprojected 
planimetric data to Web Mercator to match WMTS and a data shift is showing in ESRI when no 
transformation is applied or should be needed. Sanborn continues to investigate and may need 
to reach out to ESRI support to understand how software applies transformations/projections. 
Sanborn provided a few orthoimagery tiles in GeoTiff format and State Plane projection for 
client to review/compare via FTP on Nov. 17, 2021. Sanborn provided a sample of the 
planimetrics in web Mercator format via FTP on Dec. 16, 2021.

Solano County ReGIS Meeting 
Meeting Minutes – November 17, 2021 
 
Stew called to order the regular meeting at 9:05 am on November 17, 2021 via MS Teams. 
I. 
Introductions 
The following persons were present: Stewart Bruce, Nellie Dimalanta, Donald Hildebrandt, 
Jordan Santos, Jasmin Acuna, Bao Nguyen, Danny Fortson, Daniel Machado, Rowland Roberts, 
Jorge Giocochea, Jeffrey Bertany, Pam Caronongan, Curt Corbett. 
II. 
Approval of Meeting Minutes and New Business 
A. October Meeting Minutes: No additional comments were brought up, moved for acceptance 
by Stew and seconded by Jordan. 
B. No new business. 
III. Discussion: 
A. Solano County Governance survey results: 
1. Stew – thanks the group for feedback for the Top 5 priorities which are Data Quality, Data 
Architecture, Access, Data Stewardship and Performance. 
2. Other governance areas that didn’t make it to the top 5 but just as critical are Strategic 
Plan, Daily Usage, Communications, and Training & Development. 
3. Data quality – not a surprise as this is at the top of the list for priorities. Parcel data and 
addressing datasets are improving daily on the County side. As members are data 
sharing more with agreements in place, there is an ongoing effort to ensure data is 
maintained. Stew may send out another survey about agencies’ data quality/needs 
assessment. 
4. County plans to schedule training on the Azure portal for internal County staff and ReGIS 
members. 
5. Danny F asked if the data quality pertains to internally and/or externally shared data? 
Per Stew, both… some stakeholders do not have the capacity to maintain data integrity 
and rely on outside resources such as the County to provide additional services to assist 
with staying up to speed with their ongoing community growth. The County has pledged 
to help all ReGIS stakeholders as a consortium, to continue to work through these 
challenges. 
B. Solano County Website – Daniel. Consolidating to a single index environment for ReGIS 
members and the public. December goal to build a skeletal framework in hopes to have 
ReGIS members test the site at the beginning of the new year. Stew would like to upload 
past meeting minutes to the new website. 
C. Aerial imagery – Stew. 6-yr contract, Urban and SOI 3” res annually, planimetrics updated 
annually, Lidar spread out over a couple of years to be captured at high res. Sanborn

contract and MOU will be sent out to all partners at the end of the week, for review by the

flights with the entire county at 3” res, annual data capture for urban core, then every 3rd year 
flying unincorporated areas. 
D. COST SHARING IS THE SAME DOLLAR AMOUNTS FROM PREVIOUS YEARS. 
E. Geocomm – converted street CL to new NextGen 911 format will make accessible to ReGIS 
partners via the portal. Working on a proposal for funding aimed at improving streets and 
address point datasets. Working with Vallejo, Vacaville and Fairfield on address changes 
cities are implementing in their jurisdictions. 
F. BCS application – Stew. Asked feedback about the application. 
1. Jasmin – FF already has a 3rd party application for its address data, will BCS integrate 
with 3rd party? Per Stew, goal is for all partners to use BCS and collaboratively share 
the single countywide dataset, streamlining data updates and minimizing duplicate 
efforts in data development. BCS will be made accessible to all partners, wherein 
they are responsible for their jurisdictional data. Asking no funds from the cities to 
invest in the software. Decided to purchase the software with training, hoping by April 
2022 installation. 
G. GIS Day – Nellie. Virtual events occurring around the globe were listed on ESRI’s website

I. GIS Membership list – Nellie, primary contact for each of the agency are listed on the 
agenda. Talk to Daniel about member management system. Proud City to possibly assist 
with this. 
J. Lightning Talk volunteer for the next meeting – Pam Caronongan (?) 
IV. Action Items

C. Aerial imagery – Stew. 14 sets of hard drives of all Sanborn data deliverables will be sent to

agency agreement will be forwarded soon as well. COST SHARING IS THE SAME DOLLAR

D. NextGen 911 – County working with Geocomm, updating street CL, address point layer, and
will be accessible to ReGIS partners via the portal. Monthly updates to street data. Will move
forward with the BCS tool, approx. 5 months to go online and made accessible via portal.
E. Adding users to SC GIS portal, each ReGIS partner will have access to Azure portal with

F. Lightning Talk – no one scheduled but Donald mentioned he is working with STA and Solano
Land Trust on a project called Top 10 Walk and Bike Trails in Solano County in collaboration
with OuterSpatial, an app similar to AllTrails. Park Depts are data stewards of their
jurisdictions. Information will be on brochures and online, data consists of recreational
amenities and trails. Per STA, soft launch to be expected within the next couple of months,
may commit to a lightning talk then.
City of Fairfield Parks & Rec is a contributing member of OuterSpatial. Fairfield GIS would
like to shine alongside other agency contributors to the project but is encountering hurdles
obtaining necessary data despite upper management approvals. One suggestion from the
group is to have a timeline of when data is needed, STA is working on a soft launch date
which may help with this effort. Another approach is to develop an internal marketing

Solano County Regional GIS – Data Quality Governance 
 
DRAFT 2/15/2022 
 
Objective 
The intent and goal of this policy is to define the process under which data quality is evaluated, 
measured, and reported for each GIS dataset maintained on the GIS Portal at 
https://solanocountygis.com/portal. 
This policy impacts all data produced, or acquired through contracted services, by the Solano County 
DoIT GIS Team, those GIS datasets produced by other Solano County departments, GIS datasets shared 
with the county by Regional GIS Consortium partners, and all third-party GIS data sources such as 
private sources, non-REGIS local governments, state and/or Federal agencies. 
Controls 
In addition to this overriding policy, each dataset will have an individual control document with the 
dataset specific data quality measures included. An appendix shall be attached to this policy detailing 
where these control documents are. Each GIS dataset will have metadata, enabled through the 
appropriate ESRI metadata in both the Portal item description as well as embedded with the actual 
dataset, that shall also provide a short data quality statement. The dataset control document shall 
record the history of any data quality improvements identified from the initial data quality review; and 
record when these improvements have been accomplished. 
Decision Rights 
The data steward of each GIS dataset shall have the ultimate right and authority to improve the data 
quality of any dataset shared on the Portal. The Solano County DoIT GIS Team has the right to add a 
data quality statement to any dataset published on the Portal based on our internal data quality review 
regardless of the data steward. Any data quality issues noted on the dataset shall be shared with the 
data steward who shall be encouraged to correct them. 
Inputs 
The Solano County DoIT GIS team, or a designated contractor, shall be required to develop the dataset 
control document and perform a data quality analysis with each data delivery. 
Activities 
These are the specific minimum data quality areas that shall be evaluated, and part of the data quality 
information contained in the metadata. 
a. Topology 
 
All polygons and lines shall have their topology validated and a summary report provided. For 
polygons, the topology validation should check for overlapping features and for any gaps in the 
data. The validation should be done at the default ESRI spatial tolerance. Lines shall also be 
checked for dangling nodes as well as overlaps. Points shall be analyzed to identify any 
duplicate or multiple points at the same coordinate location. 

2 
 
b. Attributes 
 
A listing of each attribute column heading and what that attribute column means shall be 
created and attached with the metadata. If aliases are used, they should be identified. If there 
are coded attributes, then a list of what each code means is also required. An analysis of the 
attributes for inconsistences, such as an attribute that means the same thing being spelled in 
different ways, or individual features that do not have attributes at all shall also be identified. If 
external data is joined to the spatial features, then an analysis of any external attributes that do 
not have a correlated feature shall also be conducted. 
 
The data quality analysis should also examine the accuracy of external attribute data sources 
that are joined to the spatial features. 
 
c. Precision, accuracy, and scale 
Data shall be evaluated for precision and accuracy. For each dataset the scale at which the data 
was collected and intended for use at should be clearly identified. For example, planimetric 
data collected using the county high resolution aerial imagery was not collected at the same 
scale as US EPA hydrology data. Therefore, how each dataset aligns with the county aerial 
imagery shall vary. 
Each dataset control document shall outline in detail how to evaluate for this category. 
The figure below shows how these may vary with any given dataset, 
 

3 
 
d. Age of data 
The collection date shall be analyzed and reported. If any dataset is more then one year old, 
then the dataset control document should address this age issue with plans to refresh the data. 
The dataset control document shall also document the update frequency. For example, parcels 
are updated every month. 
Performance Metrics 
Performance metrics shall be clearly identified in each dataset control document along with the 
procedure to be used to validate and report these metrics.

practical experience in Geographic Information Systems and IT troubleshooting. Participants will work under the guidance of IT professional staff, gaining useful skills and habits. 
Key benefits include:
Professional Growth: Interns will gain hands-on experience in their chosen field.
Community Contribution: The work performed will directly benefit our local community.
Compensation: Interns are paid $17.60 per hour, with flexible scheduling that accommodates school commitments.
Duration: These opportunities begin in June and can extend for up to six months.
Applying is straightforward: Interested candidates should send a Letter of Interest and Resume to soco.internship@gmail.com. A Letter of Interest is just a brief explanation of what they want to learn or do during this internship.
These internships are open to all eligible young adults in California, including recent high school graduates and current college students.
